docs.title: Project Overview
docs.text:
Replace this page with a concise introduction to your project.

  • Summarize what the project does and who it is for.
  • Highlight a few standout capabilities or goals.
  • Link to the most important sections that visitors should read first.

docs.title: Getting Started Checklist
docs.text:
• [ ] Replace this checklist with your onboarding steps.
  • [ ] Point to a quick demo, screenshot, or CLI snippet.
  • [ ] Make it obvious how users should file issues or ask questions.

docs.title: Learn More
docs.text:
• Add sections for features, architecture, or roadmap once you have real content.
  • Remove any placeholder callouts before publishing.

Remember: the homepage is the first impression—keep it focused on user outcomes.

docs.title: Build & Release Workflow
docs.text: Document how to produce artifacts and publish them to your users.

docs.title: Pipelines
docs.text:
• Describe the build tools, CI/CD jobs, and environments involved.
  • Note any secrets or credentials required along the way.

docs.title: Local Development
docs.text:
• Provide commands for running the full build on a developer workstation.
  • Highlight the fastest feedback loop for common changes.

docs.title: Publishing
docs.text:
• Explain how releases are versioned and tagged.
  • Document what triggers an APT repository update and how to validate it.

🔁 Keep this page current—stale build docs are worse than no docs.

docs.title: Customization Guide
docs.text: Explain how downstream teams should adapt this template for their own needs.

docs.title: Brand and Messaging
docs.text:
• Document what assets to update (logos, colors, product names).
  • Clarify any style or tone guidelines.

docs.title: Feature Toggles
docs.text:
• List optional components and how to enable or disable them.
  • Note which settings require rebuilds or redeployments.

docs.title: Extending the Repository
docs.text:
• Outline how to add new packages, documentation pages, or automation steps.
  • Include links to scripts or pipelines that must be touched.

✏️ Replace each section with concrete instructions before sharing the site publicly.

docs.title: Architecture Notes
docs.text: Capture the decisions and trade-offs that define this project.

docs.title: System Diagram
docs.text:
• Replace this section with an updated diagram or textual description.
  • Call out core components, data flows, and external dependencies.

docs.title: Key Decisions
docs.text:
• Summarize major design choices and why they exist.
  • Link to ADRs or supporting documents if available.

docs.title: Future Work
docs.text:
• Outline upcoming changes that might alter the architecture.
  • Flag areas that need special attention during reviews.

🧭 Keep the content high level—implementation details belong in code or specs.

docs.title: Project Quickstart
docs.text: Follow this guide after you fork the upstream repository to prepare it for your project.

docs.title: 1. Fork the Repository
docs.text:
1. Visit the upstream project on GitHub.
  2. Click Fork and choose the owner where your template should live.

docs.title: 2. Run the Preparation Script
docs.text:
⚠️ Always review scripts before piping them to bash.

curl -sSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/<your-account>/<your-repo-name>/main/prepare-template.sh | \
  bash -s -- git@github.com:<your-account>/<your-repo-name>.git

The script performs the following:

  • Clones your fork into a fresh directory.
  • Replaces MkDocs content with placeholders ready for customization.
  • Clears the generated docs/ output (including the old APT repository layout).
  • Rebuilds the site using the placeholder content.
  • Prompts you to pick one of your local GPG keys and exports it to keys/apt-repo-pubkey.asc and docs/apt/apt-repo-pubkey.asc.

You can pass an optional second argument to choose the target directory name:

bash prepare-template.sh https://github.com/<your-account>/<your-repo-name>.git my-project-docs

docs.title: 3. Customize the Template
docs.text:
• Replace each placeholder page in mkdocs/ with real project documentation.
  • Add or adjust packages under pkgs/ as needed.
  • Regenerate the docs with ./scripts/mkdocs.sh and build the APT repo with ./scripts/mkrepo.sh.

docs.title: 4. Commit and Push
docs.text:
cd <clone-directory>
git status
git add .
git commit -m "Prepare template for <project-name>"
git push origin main

Your fork is now ready for project-specific work. Continue updating documentation, packages, and automation as your needs evolve.

docs.title: Release Notes
docs.text: Use this page to summarize what changed in each release.

docs.title: Template
docs.text:
## vX.Y.Z — YYYY-MM-DD

- Highlight the major changes or fixes.
- Note any upgrade or migration steps.
- Link to detailed changelog or pull requests if needed.

docs.title: Tips
docs.text:
• Keep entries short and focused on user impact.
  • Move completed roadmap items or deprecations here as they ship.
  • Archive older releases if the list grows too long.

📦 Replace this placeholder once you cut your first release.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: Use this page to walk newcomers through their first successful run with your project.

docs.title: Audience
docs.text:
• ⛏️ Intended users: Describe who should read this page.
  • 🧰 Requirements: List OS, tools, or credentials they need.

docs.title: Quick Start Flow
docs.text:
1. Installation – Replace with the exact commands to install or configure prerequisites.
  2. Configuration – Document any environment variables, config files, or secrets.
  3. Verification – Provide a simple command or test that confirms everything works.

docs.title: Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Keep a short FAQ for the issues you see most often.
  • Link to longer debugging guides as they evolve.

🛠️ Remove each placeholder block once you have authentic instructions.
